channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Unrelenting Assault on Aleppo Is Worst Yet in Five-Year Civil War
item.media:description: People looking for survivors on Monday at a site hit previously by an airstrike in the rebel-held Tariq al-Bab neighborhood of Aleppo, Syria.
item.description: Residents and rescuers described the bombardment as among the worst yet in the five-year war.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE and SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Syria and Russia Appear Ready to Scorch Aleppo
item.media:description: Members of the Syrian Civil Defense group recovered a body after airstrikes on Saturday in the contested city of Aleppo. More than 90 people died on Friday, and more than 100 on Saturday.
item.media:credit: Syrian Civil Defense White Helmets, via Associated Press
item.description: The Syrians and Russians appear to be mobilizing to apply a kill-all-who-resist strategy to their most ambitious target yet.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Iran Releases Homa Hoodfar, a Canadian-Iranian Professor Held Since June
item.description: Iran never said why it was holding the professor, but her release coincided with an announcement that Canada and Iran would discuss reopening embassies.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Two Years After a Night of Horror, Mexican Students Seek Answers
item.media:description: Edgar Andrés Vargas, 21, survived a night of violence in September 2014 in which 43 Mexican college students were kidnapped. He was shot in the face and has had six surgeries.
item.media:credit: Meghan Dhaliwal for The New York Times
item.description: The families of 43 kidnapped college students continue to lobby the government for justice — accompanied by students who lived through the 2014 attack.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE and PAULINA VILLEGAS
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Escuela Normal Rural Raul Isidro Burgos (Guerrero, Mexico)

item.title: Inside France’s ‘Jungle’: Desperate Migrants Keep Coming to Calais
item.media:description: Makeshift shelters in a camp known as the Jungle.
item.description: The camp perched at the edge of the English Channel has doubled in size, a highly visible symbol of Europe’s inability to cope with the migrant influx.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER and TYLER HICKS
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Russia, Jailer of Local Separatists, Welcomes Foreign Secessionists
item.description: A global troupe of marginal liberation movements invited to a curious gathering near the Kremlin included, improbably, four from the United States.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Scientists Inspect the Great Barrier Reef, From 28,000 Feet Above
item.media:description: Researchers preparing to collect data off Lizard Island, Australia, for a study of the Great Barrier Reef that will also use aerial images.
item.media:credit: Bermuda Institute of Ocean Sciences/Jpl-Caltech, via NASA
item.description: A NASA flying laboratory is using a specially designed sensor in a search for answers about what is killing large sections of the world’s coral reefs.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Changbaishan Journal: For South Koreans, a Long Detour to Their Holy Mountain
item.media:description: The crater of Baekdusan, a volcanic mountain, with the caldera lake in the background. On the border between China and North Korea, Baekdusan is revered by North and South Koreans. South Koreans have to take a detour through China to be able to climb its slopes.
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.description: For Koreans from both North and South, the Cheonji crater lake and the Baekdusan mountain on which it sits are considered the spiritual home of their nations.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: 3 Labor Activists in China Get Suspended Prison Terms
item.description: The organizers’ activities had long been tolerated, but the prosecution and sentences suggested a tougher government line now that growth is slowing.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: For Rosetta, a Landing and an Ending on a Comet
item.media:description: This false-color image, taken by the Rosetta spacecraft at a distance of 45 miles, shows the smooth region that connects the two lobes of Comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko.
item.description: The spacecraft is to end its 12-year pursuit of Comet 67P/Churyumov–Gerasimenko on Friday. Here is what the European Space Agency mission found out.
item.dc:creator: KENNETH CHANG

item.title: Iran’s Supreme Leader Advises Ahmadinejad Not to Run for President
item.media:description: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, the supreme leader of Iran, in Tehran this month. His recent statements about the former President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad make it almost impossible for Mr. Ahmadinejad to run again for the country’s leadership.
item.media:credit: Office of the Iranian Supreme Leader, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.description: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei said that the former president, known in the West for denying the Holocaust and for threats against Israel, should not be a candidate in May.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: To the Moon, North Korea? Or Does a Rocket Have a Darker Aim?
item.media:description: An illuminated globe at a science and technology complex in Pyongyang, North Korea. Space officials say a moonshot is the nation’s goal.
item.description: The North explains a rocket engine test as a moonshot, but intelligence agencies are exploring another option: the beginnings of a missile that could reach the American mainland.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER and WILLIAM J. BROAD

item.title: Mexico Extinguishes Fuel Tanker Fire Off Gulf Coast
item.media:description: A tanker belonging to Mexico’s state oil company caught fire after an explosion on Saturday morning. Firefighting crews extinguished the blaze roughly 30 hours later.
item.media:credit: Mexico Navy, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.description: Crew members were safely evacuated and no extensive spill had been detected, but the episode was another blow to the state oil company.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Socialist Party Sees Deep Losses in Spain Elections
item.media:description: Inigo Urkullu, a Basque Nationalist Party candidate, after wining a regional vote on Sunday that has national implications.
item.description: The regional votes have implications on whether the country’s four national parties can end the nine-month deadlock in Spain’s national politics.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Bosnian Serbs Keep Holiday in Vote Assailed as Illegal
item.description: Bosnia’s international peace envoy, Valentin Inzko, said that the referendum was an attack on Bosnia’s constitutional order and was not legally valid.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Plan to Let Migrant Children Attend School Enrages Many Greeks
item.media:description: Jihan Sheikh Mohammed, center, with some of her children, including Mariya bint Loqman Abdlkarim, 9, at a refugee camp in Oraiokastro, Greece. They fled from Syria.
item.media:credit: Angelos Tzortzinis for The New York Times
item.description: Citing health concerns and cultural differences, parents and officials in Greece want to keep refugee camp children out of local schools.
item.dc:creator: NIKI KITSANTONIS
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Activist in South Korea Dies of Injuries From Police Water Cannon
item.media:description: A South Korean farmer protesting the government’s agricultural policy in Seoul last week. Another activist farmer, Baek Nam-gi, who was struck by a police water cannon at a protest last year, died on Sunday.
item.description: The activist, Baek Nam-gi, who had been expelled from school twice for protests against the dictator Park Chung-hee, was injured while opposing Mr. Park’s daughter, President Park Geun-hye.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Writer Charged With Insulting Islam Is Killed as Extremism Boils Over in Jordan
item.media:description: The police cordoned off the area where Nahed Hattar, a Jordanian writer, was fatally shot in Amman on Sunday.
item.description: Nahed Hattar, who was recently arrested after sharing a cartoon on Facebook that offended some Muslims, was killed outside a court in Amman.
item.dc:creator: RANA F. SWEIS and PETER BAKER

item.title: China Hunts for Scientific Glory, and Aliens, With New Telescope
item.media:description: The new Five-hundred-meter Aperture Spherical Telescope, or FAST, in Guizhou Province, is roughly twice as sensitive as the world’s next-biggest single-dish radio telescope.
item.description: The telescope, which officially began operating on Sunday in a majestic but poor part of Guizhou Province, embodies China’s ambitions as a scientific power.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY and ADAM WU

item.title: Sinosphere: Jewish and Chinese: Explaining a Shared Identity
item.media:description: Residents in what was a Jewish neighborhood, next to the site of the old synagogue, in Kaifeng.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: Moshe Bernstein, a researcher based in Western Australia, discusses the revival of an ancient Jewish community facing a government clampdown.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Sidelined at the U.N., a Frustrated Taiwan Presses On
item.media:description: Joanne Ou, the director of Taiwan’s United Nations Task Force, at her office in Manhattan this month. Ms. Ou is responsible for efforts to gain greater recognition for Taiwanese.
item.media:credit: Bryan Thomas for The New York Times
item.description: China has for decades chipped away at Taiwan’s global standing, but now the island is pushing back with behind-the-scenes diplomacy and soft power.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

item.title: What in the World: Buy Me Some Peanuts and Wiener Nougat
item.description: The similarities between the Finnish game of pesapallo and baseball are striking, as are the differences. (Wiener Nougat, a Finnish candy, is not like Cracker Jack.)
item.dc:creator: VICTOR MATHER

item.title: What in the World: Australia Is Not as Down Under as Everyone Thinks It Is
item.description: That map of Australia you have? It’s wrong. And the whole country is going to officially relocate north to correct the error.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: To Save Mosul, Arm the Sunnis
item.media:description: Sunni fighters gathering this month in Shirqat, Iraq.
item.description: Liberating Iraq’s second largest city from the Islamic State will require more than air power and Shiite militias.
item.dc:creator: JAMAL AL-DHARI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Hong Kong and the Realities of China’s Rise
item.description: Like the rest of the world, Hong Kongers will have to cope with a more powerful and assertive China.
item.dc:creator: YUEN YING CHAN

item.title: Opinion: Forget Trump’s Wall: For Mexico, the Election Is About Nafta
item.description: With both candidates bashing free trade, how their anger translates into policy is the big question south of the border.
item.dc:creator: IOAN GRILLO

item.title: Postcard From the Hajj: A Pilgrim’s Progress: Checking Mecca Off My Bucket List
item.media:description: “Pilgrims surprised me with their warmth.”
item.description: This reporter’s long-dreamed-of journey to explore the heart of Islam revealed surprises, debunked stereotypes and produced one stunning bird video.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Postscript: One Year Later, a Tip About a Border Crossing Pays Off
item.media:description: Laborers transported ammonium nitrate at the crossing from Akcakale, Turkey, into Syria in April 2015. The compound, a common fertilizer, has been used by terrorists to create explosives.
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.description: How New York Times reporting may have made the Middle East just a little bit safer.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and KARAM SHOUMALI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT
